verses.text: Sarah lived one hundred and twenty-seven years; these were the years of Sarah's life.
verses.comment: This verse highlights Sarah's advanced age, underscoring the extraordinary nature of Isaac's birth as fulfillment of God's promise (see Gen. 21:2).

verses.text: Sarah died in Kiriath-arba (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan, and Abraham went in to mourn for Sarah and weep for her.
verses.comment: Abraham's weeping for Sarah shows the deep covenantal relationship of marriage. Hebron (Kiriath-arba) carries significance as a locus for the ancestors' faith journey.

verses.text: Abraham rose up from before his dead and spoke to the sons of Heth, saying,
verses.comment: The sons of Heth (Hittites) were local Canaanite inhabitants. Abraham's respectful dealings suggest a theme of witness and peaceful coexistence with the nations.

verses.text: "I am a stranger and a sojourner among you. Give me property among you for a burial site, that I may bury my dead out of my sight."
verses.comment: Despite the promised land, Abraham acknowledges his pilgrim status (cf. Heb. 11:13), reflecting humility before God and men. The theme of pilgrimage prefigures the faithful's heavenly journey.

verses.text: The sons of Heth answered Abraham,
verses.comment: The Hittites’ respectful response to Abraham emphasizes his reputation and relationship with surrounding peoples.

verses.text: "Hear us, my lord; you are a mighty prince among us. Bury your dead in the choicest of our tombs. None of us will refuse you his tomb to bury your dead."
verses.comment: Abraham is called a 'mighty prince,' hinting at the respect God's chosen ones receive even among nonbelievers. This status points to the universal respect for true faith.

verses.text: Then Abraham stood up, and bowed himself down before the people of the land, before the sons of Heth.
verses.comment: Abraham’s humility and public respect demonstrates godly character. True believers witness through both word and deed.

verses.text: He spoke with them, saying, "If you are willing for me to bury my dead out of my sight, hear me, and speak to Ephron the son of Zohar for me,
verses.comment: Abraham requests a specific burial place, emphasizing order and propriety in sacred obligations, which reflects a broader tradition of reverence for burial.

verses.text: "that he may give me the cave of Machpelah, which he owns, at the end of his field. Let him give it to me among you for the full price as a burial site."
verses.comment: The cave of Machpelah would later be the family tomb. Abraham’s insistence on paying full price underlines justice, and foreshadows reverent traditions regarding sacred spaces.

verses.text: Now Ephron was sitting among the sons of Heth. And Ephron the Hittite answered Abraham in the hearing of the sons of Heth, all who went in at the gate of his city, saying,
verses.comment: Business at the city gate marks official and public agreements. Trust and communal witness are fundamental in biblical covenants and foreshadow the visible aspect of faith communities.

verses.text: "No, my lord, listen to me: I give you the field and the cave that is in it; in the presence of my people I give it to you. Bury your dead."
verses.comment: Ephron makes a generous offer, though social custom required a formal acceptance of payment. Public generosity and propriety reflect God’s model of honorable dealings.

verses.text: Abraham bowed before the people of the land.
verses.comment: Further humility and gratitude highlight Abraham’s example as a leader marked by peace and diplomacy.

verses.text: And he spoke to Ephron in the hearing of the people of the land, saying, "If you will, please listen to me. I will give the price of the field. Accept it from me, that I may bury my dead there."
verses.comment: Abraham insists on a legitimate, uncompromised transaction, modeling moral uprightness. This foreshadows sacred trust in handling spiritual matters among God’s people.

verses.text: Ephron answered Abraham, saying to him,
verses.comment: Negotiation in the Ancient Near East culture was expected to show mutual respect and honor.

verses.text: "My lord, listen to me: the land is worth four hundred shekels of silver. What is that between you and me? Bury your dead."
verses.comment: Ephron names a price, allowing Abraham to pay. The details provide insight into economic practices and the value of transparent dealings amongst God's people.

verses.text: So Abraham agreed with Ephron, and Abraham weighed out to Ephron the silver that he had named in the hearing of the sons of Heth, four hundred shekels of silver, according to the weights current among the merchants.
verses.comment: Abraham’s honesty and fulfillment of custom contrast with later abuses of sacred obligations (cf. Jer. 32:9-10). This scene grounds religious authority in visible, verifiable actions.

verses.text: So the field of Ephron in Machpelah, which was before Mamre, the field and the cave that was in it, and all the trees that were in the field, within all its borders, were deeded
verses.comment: The specific mention of legal ownership sets a precedent for later sacred inheritances. Burial in consecrated ground will be a repeated pattern in the history of God’s people.

verses.text: to Abraham as a possession in the presence of the sons of Heth, before all who entered the gate of his city.
verses.comment: This public, communal transaction guarantees the legitimacy of Abraham’s claim, hinting at God’s pattern of acting visibly in history through covenant and witnesses.

verses.text: After this, Abraham buried Sarah his wife in the cave of the field of Machpelah east of Mamre (that is, Hebron) in the land of Canaan.
verses.comment: The burial at Machpelah initiates a tradition of honoring ancestors—prefiguring later memorial practices and the concept of the communion of saints.

verses.text: So the field and the cave that is in it were deeded to Abraham by the sons of Heth as a possession for a burial site.
verses.comment: This legally binding property becomes a perpetual memorial. Respect for the resting places of the departed anticipates later traditions within the whole people of God.
